beginner.definition: A greeting used when meeting someone
A word used when leaving
A polite word used when asking for something
A polite word used to show gratitude
A word used to apologize
A word used to agree or confirm
A word used to disagree or refuse
A word by which a person or thing is known
A person you know well and like
A group of people related by blood or marriage
A female parent
A male parent
A male sibling
beginner.example: My brother is younger than me.

beginner.definition: A female sibling
A young person
A very young child
An adult male
beginner.example: The man is reading a newspaper.

beginner.definition: An adult female
More than one person
beginner.example: Many people are at the park.

beginner.definition: A person who helps students learn
A person who learns at school
A place where children learn
beginner.example: My daughter starts school next week.

beginner.definition: A set of written or printed pages
A tool for writing with ink
beginner.example: Write your name with a pen.

beginner.definition: A tool for writing or drawing
beginner.example: Draw a picture with a pencil.

beginner.definition: Material for writing or printing on
beginner.example: Please give me a piece of paper.

beginner.definition: A container for carrying things
A piece of furniture for writing or working
beginner.example: The computer is on the desk.

beginner.definition: A seat for one person
A piece of furniture with a flat top
beginner.example: The food is on the table.

beginner.definition: An opening in a wall for light and air
A movable barrier for entering or leaving a place
A small container for drinking
beginner.example: She drank tea from a cup.

beginner.definition: A flat dish for food
beginner.example: Put your food on the plate.

beginner.definition: A tool with prongs for eating
beginner.example: Use a fork to eat salad.

beginner.definition: A tool with a round end for eating
beginner.example: Stir your soup with a spoon.

beginner.definition: A container for liquids
beginner.example: He bought a bottle of water.

beginner.definition: A device that shows time
beginner.example: The clock is on the wall.

beginner.definition: Something that makes things bright
A covering for the foot
beginner.example: Put on your shoe before going out.

beginner.definition: A piece of clothing for the upper body
Clothing for the legs
A piece of clothing for women
A covering for the head
A large vehicle for many passengers
beginner.example: We go to school by bus.

beginner.definition: A long vehicle that moves on tracks
A vehicle with two wheels
beginner.example: He rides his bike every day.

beginner.definition: A vehicle with four wheels
A way for cars and people to travel
A public road in a city or town
A place with grass and trees for people to enjoy
A place where plants and flowers grow
beginner.example: She waters the garden every day.

beginner.definition: A colorful part of a plant
Green plants that cover the ground
beginner.example: The grass is wet with dew.

beginner.definition: A flat green part of a plant
beginner.example: The leaf fell from the tree.

beginner.definition: A tall plant with a trunk and branches
A large stream of water
beginner.example: The river flows to the sea.

beginner.definition: A very high hill
A large body of salt water
beginner.example: The sea is blue and beautiful.

beginner.definition: A large area of water surrounded by land
Water that falls from clouds
beginner.example: The rain made the ground wet.

beginner.definition: Soft white pieces of frozen water
Air that moves
A white or gray mass in the sky
A bright point of light in the night sky
beginner.example: I see many stars at night.

beginner.definition: A round object that shines at night
Something you eat
A clear liquid that people and animals drink
A common food made from flour
A small white or brown grain eaten as food
A round object from a bird, eaten as food
Food from animals
beginner.example: Chicken is a type of meat.

beginner.definition: An animal that lives in water and is eaten as food
Food that grows on trees or plants
A plant or part of a plant used as food
A round fruit with red or green skin
A long yellow fruit
A round orange fruit
A long orange vegetable
A round vegetable that grows underground
beginner.example: Potatoes are used to make chips.

beginner.definition: A red fruit used in salads and cooking
A white liquid from cows, used as a drink
A drink made from fruit or vegetables
A hot drink made from leaves
A hot drink made from coffee beans
A sweet substance used in food and drinks
A white substance used to flavor food
The first meal of the day
The meal eaten in the middle of the day
The main meal of the day, eaten in the evening
To put food in your mouth and swallow it
To take liquid into your mouth and swallow it
To prepare food by heating it
Having a high temperature
Having a low temperature
Large in size
Little in size
Feeling good or joyful
Feeling unhappy
beginner.example: He is sad about the news.

beginner.definition: Feeling the need to rest or sleep

intermediate.definition: Money put into something to make a profit
intermediate.example: Real estate is a good long-term investment.

intermediate.definition: To change to fit new conditions
intermediate.example: You must adapt to new situations.

intermediate.definition: A condition that makes something easier or better
intermediate.example: Speaking English is an advantage when traveling.

intermediate.definition: Suggestions about what you think someone should do
To influence or change something
intermediate.example: The weather can affect your mood.

intermediate.definition: A strong desire to do or achieve something
intermediate.example: Her ambition is to be a scientist.

intermediate.definition: To study something closely and carefully
intermediate.example: We need to analyze the results.

intermediate.definition: To come near or nearer to something
intermediate.example: The train is approaching the station.

intermediate.definition: A disagreement or reason for/against something
intermediate.example: They had an argument about politics.

intermediate.definition: To put things in a particular order
intermediate.example: She arranged the books on the shelf.

intermediate.definition: To think something is true without proof
intermediate.example: Don't assume he knows the answer.

intermediate.definition: To try to do something
intermediate.example: She attempted to solve the puzzle.

intermediate.definition: Able to be used or obtained
intermediate.example: The book is available at the library.

intermediate.definition: The usual or typical amount
A good or helpful result
A difficult task or problem
intermediate.example: Learning a new language is a challenge.

intermediate.definition: A quality that makes something different
To look at similarities and differences
To try to win against others
Not simple; having many parts
A feeling of worry or interest
To show something is true or correct
A result of an action
intermediate.example: There are consequences for being late.

intermediate.definition: To think about something carefully
To be made up of
intermediate.example: The team consists of five people.

intermediate.definition: Happening all the time; not changing
To build or make something
To give or add something
Easy and suitable for your needs
To make something new
To say what is wrong with something
A choice made after thinking
intermediate.example: Making a decision can be hard.

intermediate.definition: To become less or smaller
To explain the meaning of a word or idea
To show how something works
To need someone or something for support
To say what something is like
To grow or improve something
A way in which things are not the same
intermediate.example: There is a big difference between the two.

intermediate.definition: Not easy; hard to do
To talk about something with others
A change that is caused by something
intermediate.example: The medicine had a good effect.

intermediate.definition: Hard work or energy used to do something
To give someone confidence or hope
The natural world around us
To guess the amount or value of something
Facts or information that show something is true
intermediate.example: There is no evidence of a crime.

intermediate.definition: To look at something carefully
To make something bigger
Knowledge or skill from doing something
intermediate.example: She has a lot of experience.

intermediate.definition: A person with special knowledge or skill
intermediate.example: He is an expert in computers.

intermediate.definition: One of the things that influences a result
intermediate.example: Weather is a factor in farming.

intermediate.definition: Well known or easily recognized
An important part or quality of something
To pay special attention to something
The purpose or job of something
intermediate.example: The function of a pen is to write.

intermediate.definition: Something you want to achieve
intermediate.example: Her goal is to learn English.

intermediate.definition: To recognize or name something
A strong effect or influence
intermediate.example: The new law had a big impact.

intermediate.definition: To have something as part of a group
To become larger or greater
To show or point out
A single person or thing
To have an effect on someone or something
To give information to someone
intermediate.example: Please inform me of any changes.

intermediate.definition: To make someone feel they want to do something
To plan or mean to do something
A feeling of wanting to know or learn about something
intermediate.example: She has an interest in music.

intermediate.definition: To explain the meaning of something
To make someone known to another person
To include someone or something in an activity
An important topic or problem
Very important or large
To control or organize something
intermediate.example: She manages a team of five.

intermediate.definition: To find the size or amount of something
intermediate.example: Measure the length of the table.

intermediate.definition: To talk about something briefly
intermediate.example: He mentioned the problem in his report.

intermediate.definition: A way of doing something
Bad or harmful
To watch something carefully
intermediate.example: Observe the animals in the zoo.

intermediate.definition: To happen or take place
What someone thinks about something
A chance to do something
To arrange or plan something
To take part in something
Specific or special
To do an action or activity
intermediate.example: She performed well in the test.

intermediate.definition: Good or helpful
Something that might happen
intermediate.example: There is a possibility of rain.

intermediate.definition: To say what will happen in the future
To like one thing more than another
To stop something from happening
intermediate.example: Wash your hands to prevent illness.

intermediate.definition: A series of actions to achieve something
To make or create something
How good or bad something is
intermediate.example: The quality of the food is high.

intermediate.definition: The amount or number of something
intermediate.example: We need a large quantity of paper.

intermediate.definition: To act in response to something
intermediate.example: How did you react to the news?

intermediate.definition: To suggest something as good
intermediate.example: Can you recommend a good restaurant?

intermediate.definition: To make something smaller or less
To show or think about something
To need something

advanced.definition: Having more than one possible meaning

advanced.example: Scientists analyze data to find patterns.
Love is the antithesis of hate.

advanced.definition: To state a fact or belief confidently
To evaluate or estimate the nature, ability, or quality of something
advanced.example: The teacher will assess your progress.

advanced.definition: A tendency to favor one side or opinion
advanced.example: The article showed a clear bias.

advanced.definition: To agree with someone or something
An idea or feeling that a word invokes

advanced.example: There is a consensus among experts.

advanced.definition: To say the opposite of something
A standard by which something is judged
To reach a conclusion by reasoning
advanced.example: We can deduce the answer from the facts.

advanced.definition: To get something from a source

advanced.example: There is a dichotomy between theory and practice.

advanced.definition: A difference between things that should be the same
advanced.example: There is a discrepancy in the data.

advanced.definition: To draw out a response or reaction
Lasting for a very short time
advanced.example: The beauty of the sunset was ephemeral.

advanced.definition: Open to more than one interpretation
Intended for or understood by only a small group
To be a typical example of something

advanced.example: We discussed every facet of the problem.

advanced.definition: Faithfulness to a person or idea
advanced.example: He showed great fidelity to his beliefs.

advanced.definition: Incapable of producing any useful result
A system in which people are ranked
advanced.example: The company has a clear hierarchy.

advanced.definition: A proposed explanation based on evidence

advanced.example: Indigenous people live in the rainforest.

advanced.definition: To deduce or conclude from evidence
advanced.example: We can infer the meaning from context.

advanced.definition: To introduce new ideas or methods
To suggest or hint at something bad
advanced.example: He insinuated that she was lying.

advanced.definition: To place side by side for contrast
A figure of speech comparing two things
advanced.example: She used a metaphor in her poem.
The city is notorious for traffic.

advanced.definition: No longer used; out of date
A statement that seems contradictory but may be true
advanced.example: It's a paradox that standing is tiring.
The myth was perpetuated by stories.

advanced.definition: An earlier event used as an example

advanced.example: The author lived a reclusive life.

advanced.definition: Finding something good without looking for it

advanced.example: He is tenacious in his work.

advanced.definition: A feeling of fear about something that may happen

advanced.example: He is zealous about his work.
He was cognizant of the risks.

advanced.definition: A sign that something is coming
advanced.example: Dark clouds are a harbinger of rain.

advanced.definition: Placing things side by side for contrast
advanced.example: The juxtaposition of old and new was striking.
The festival was a kaleidoscope of colors.
He was obstinate about his decision.

advanced.definition: Done with little effort or reflection

advanced.example: The city had a renaissance in art.

advanced.definition: Dislike of people from other countries
A person who is fanatical about a cause
advanced.example: He was a zealot for environmental causes.
